misconceptions.name: Hardcoding the grade instead of reading it from user input
misconceptions.description: The program never asks the user for a numeric grade. Instead, it reads four doubles for point coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) that are irrelevant to the grading task, and then hardcodes `int grade = 95;`. As a result, the computed letter grade does not depend on any user-provided grade value, which diverges from the requirement to "read a numeric grade (0-100)".
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that setting `int grade = 95;` inside `main` is an acceptable way to provide the grade to be classified, and that they do not need to prompt for and read the grade from the keyboard for this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should prompt the user with something like `Enter grade: ` and then call a Scanner method (e.g., `nextInt()` or `nextDouble()`) to read the numeric grade from the keyboard into a variable. All subsequent conditional logic should use that input-derived variable so that different user inputs produce different corresponding letter grades.
symptoms: Program prompts for `x1`/`y1` and `x2`/`y2` instead of `Enter grade:`.
The variable `grade` is assigned a fixed literal value (`95`) rather than being read from `input`.
Changing what the user types for the coordinates does not change the printed letter grade, because the grade is not based on input at all.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused a distance-between-points example and appended the grading logic at the end, focusing on the if-statements and overlooking the requirement to replace the earlier I/O with a grade prompt and read. This suggests a procedural lapse in translating the problem specification into the correct input operations rather than a lack of knowledge of how to use Scanner (since they do use it correctly for the point coordinates).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the unrelated code that asks for points and computes a distance. Instead, prompt the user with `System.out.print("Enter grade: ");` and then read a single numeric value into `grade`, for example: `int grade = input.nextInt();`. Use that `grade` variable in your conditional logic so the output depends on what the user types.
related_concepts: Using Scanner to read user input
Connecting program input to later computation
Following the problem specification when designing input/output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the only occurrence of `grade` in the code is `int grade = 95;`, and there is no call to `input.nextInt()` or similar for the grade, while Scanner is clearly used for other variables.

evidence.note: The program reads four doubles for coordinates but never prompts for or reads a grade; instead, it hardcodes `grade` as 95.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using independent if statements with overlapping grade ranges (no else-if)
misconceptions.description:
The grading logic uses a sequence of separate `if` statements with only lower-bound checks (`grade >= 90`, `grade >= 80`, etc.). Because these conditions overlap and are not connected with `else if`, a high grade (e.g., 95) satisfies multiple conditions and causes multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) to be printed instead of exactly one correct letter.

This breaks the intended mapping of each numeric range to a single letter grade and affects all of the A/B/C/D categories, even though they are implemented with the correct comparison operators individually.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that writing a series of `if` statements with descending thresholds (90, 80, 70, 60) is enough to ensure that only the appropriate block runs, almost as if the later `if`s were automatically treated like `else if` or as if the ranges didn't overlap.
misconceptions.correct_understanding:
In Java, each `if` statement is evaluated independently. If multiple `if` conditions are true, all of their bodies will execute. To implement mutually exclusive numeric ranges for grades, you must either:
- Use an `if` / `else if` / `else` chain in descending order (e.g., `if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ...`) so that only the first matching branch executes, or
- Write non-overlapping conditions that include both lower and upper bounds (e.g., `if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100)`, `else if (grade >= 80 && grade <= 89)`, etc.).
symptoms: For `grade = 95`, the program prints A, B, C, and D on separate lines instead of just A.
For `grade = 85` (if the grade were read from input or changed), the program would print B, C, and D instead of just B.
All the conditions `grade >= 90`, `grade >= 80`, `grade >= 70`, and `grade >= 60` can be true at the same time for high grades because they overlap and are not tied together with `else if`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how control flow behaves with multiple `if` statements versus an `if`/`else if` chain. The student is likely thinking in terms of a conceptual ladder of ranges but did not realize that, without `else`, Java does not stop after the first true condition. They also rely solely on lower-bound checks, which creates overlapping ranges when not combined with `else if`.
related_concepts: Control flow and short-circuiting in conditional chains
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence because the code clearly uses five independent `if` statements with overlapping `>=` and `<` checks, which by Java semantics will all fire whenever their conditions are true, leading to multiple letter outputs.

evidence.note: All grade checks are written as separate `if` statements with overlapping ranges; for a high grade, several of these conditions are true and multiple letters are printed.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded Input Instead of Reading from Keyboard
misconceptions.description: The student failed to read the numeric grade input from the user/keyboard using the Scanner object. Instead, they hardcoded the grade variable to a constant value.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe that hardcoding a test value is sufficient for the final submission, or they forgot to replace the hardcoded value with the required input reading function call (e.g., input.nextInt()).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt the user and use a Scanner method (like nextInt or nextDouble, followed by casting if necessary) to read the input value directly from the console.
symptoms: Program always uses the same input value (95)
Missing call to input.nextInt() for the grade variable
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation or confusion over when to use test data vs. user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remember to use the Scanner object to get the grade value from the user instead of assigning a fixed number to the variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The line `int grade = 95;` directly contradicts the requirement to read the grade input, and no input reading function is executed prior to this definition.

evidence.note: The grade is hardcoded, preventing user entry as required by the problem statement.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Independent If Statements for Mutually Exclusive Ranges
misconceptions.description: The student used multiple independent 'if' statements to define grade ranges (A, B, C, D, F). Since these checks are not chained using 'else if', a single grade score (like 95) satisfies multiple conditions (>=90, >=80, >=70, >=60), leading to multiple incorrect outputs ('A', 'B', 'C', 'D').
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that ordering independent 'if' checks from highest to lowest is sufficient to create mutually exclusive classification, or they do not understand that control flow continues to check subsequent 'if' blocks even after a condition is met.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When classifying data into mutually exclusive categories based on overlapping numeric ranges, conditional statements must be chained using 'if-else if-else' to prevent execution of subsequent checks once a match is found.
symptoms: Multiple letter grades printed for a single input
Incorrect classification logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of comparison flow and the role of 'else if' in conditional structures.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure that once a grade range is identified (e.g., 90-100 is 'A'), the program skips all subsequent range checks. Use the 'else if' keyword to connect your conditions.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure clearly shows five independent 'if' conditions, which causes the observed error for high grades.

evidence.note: All conditions are independent 'if' statements, leading to multiple outputs for high grades (e.g., 95 prints A, B, C, D).

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Non-exclusive conditional logic
misconceptions.description: Student uses independent if statements instead of if-else if chains, causing multiple letter grades to print for a single numeric grade value.
misconceptions.student_belief: Each grade threshold should be checked independently, and if multiple thresholds are met, all corresponding letter grades should be printed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Only one letter grade should be assigned per numeric grade. Use if-else if chains so that once a condition matches, subsequent conditions are not evaluated. The ranges should be mutually exclusive.
symptoms: Multiple letter grades print for a single input (e.g., grade 95 prints 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D')
Output does not match expected behavior (one letter per grade)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student does not understand the difference between independent if statements (all execute if true) and if-else if chains (mutually exclusive execution).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace independent if statements with if-else if-else chains. Check the most restrictive conditions first (grade >= 90) and use 'else if' for subsequent checks so only one branch executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the student's code shows all five independent if statements executing, resulting in four simultaneous print statements (A, B, C, D). This is unambiguous evidence of the misconception.

evidence.note: All five if statements are independent and will all evaluate for a given grade. With grade=95, all first four conditions are true, so A, B, C, and D all print.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded value instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: Student assigns a hardcoded constant value (95) to the grade variable instead of reading it from user input via Scanner.
misconceptions.student_belief: The grade value can be hardcoded as a constant for testing purposes, or the student forgot to implement input reading.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade must be read from user input using Scanner.nextInt(). The program should prompt the user with 'Enter grade: ' and then read the numeric input.
symptoms: Program always uses grade=95 regardless of user input
User is not prompted to enter a grade
Program cannot process different grade values
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation; student did not replace the placeholder/test value with actual Scanner input logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace 'int grade = 95;' with 'System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();' to properly read and prompt for user input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence. The code explicitly shows 'int grade = 95;' which is a hardcoded literal. The Scanner object is created but never used for grade input.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from user input via Scanner.

misconceptions.name: Grade is hard-coded instead of read from the user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads the numeric grade that it is supposed to classify. Instead of prompting the user for a grade and using Scanner to read it, the code assigns a fixed value `int grade = 95;`. This means the grading logic always runs on 95 regardless of what the user types (the only user input taken is for the unrelated distance calculation). Rubric impact: this yields 0/1 for 'Reading numeric grade input'. Overall, with this and the range errors described in the other misconception, the solution scores 2/5 (only the F handling and use of an integer grade value are effectively correct for Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that it is acceptable to test or implement the grade calculation using a fixed value like 95 instead of actually reading the grade from the user, or they may think the earlier Scanner input for the points is sufficient for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must specifically prompt for and read a numeric grade from the keyboard (e.g., using `Scanner` and `nextInt()` or `nextDouble()`), store it in a variable, and then use that value to decide which letter grade to print.
symptoms: The program always evaluates the grade logic with the value 95.
Changing user input does not change the letter-grade output, only the distance output.
There is no prompt like 'Enter grade:' and no `nextInt()`/`nextDouble()` call for the grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing a previous program (for distance) and appending grade logic without fully adapting it to the new specification, or focusing on testing the conditions with a single constant rather than wiring it to user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded `int grade = 95;` with a prompt and a `Scanner` read, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();` so that the grade classification actually depends on what the user types.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly uses a constant grade of 95 and never calls any input method for the grade, while the problem statement explicitly requires reading a numeric grade.

evidence.note: The grade is set to a fixed constant 95 instead of being read from the user, and there is no preceding prompt or input for the grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Overlapping grade conditions due to separate if statements with only lower bounds
misconceptions.description:
The student uses five independent `if` statements with only lower-bound checks (`>= 90`, `>= 80`, `>= 70`, `>= 60`, `< 60`) instead of mutually exclusive conditions (either via `if`/`else if`/`else` or explicit lower-and-upper bounds). For many grades, this prints multiple letters instead of exactly one. For example, grade 95 will print A, B, C, and D; grade 85 will print B, C, and D. This breaks the intended mapping of numeric ranges to a single letter grade.

Rubric impact:
- 'Correct Boolean ranges for A and B': 0/1, because A and B ranges overlap and both can print.
- 'Correct Boolean ranges for C and D': 0/1, because these ranges also overlap with each other and with higher grades.
- 'Correct handling of F (default/else)': effectively 1/1, since `if (grade < 60)` prints only F when grade is below 60.
- 'Mapping each range to correct letter output': 0/1, since many inputs produce multiple letters.
Combined with the input issue above, the overall score for Q3 is 2/5.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that checking thresholds in descending order with separate `if` statements (e.g., `if (grade >= 90)`, `if (grade >= 80)`, etc.) is enough to classify the grade into a single letter, assuming that the earlier checks somehow prevent later ones from running, or that only the 'best' match will effectively count.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, each `if` condition is evaluated independently unless it is explicitly chained using `else if` or `else`. To ensure that exactly one letter is printed, the grade ranges must be mutually exclusive: either by using an `if`/`else if`/`else` chain (e.g., `if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ...`) or by giving each `if` a lower and upper bound (e.g., `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)`).
symptoms: For grade 95, the output would be: A, B, C, and D on separate lines.
For grade 85, the output would be: B, C, and D.
For grade 75, the output would be: C and D.
Program does not produce exactly one letter grade for many valid inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding how multiple `if` statements behave vs. an `if`/`else if` chain and how to construct non-overlapping numeric ranges. The student relies only on lower bounds and ordering, without realizing that all `if` conditions are checked independently.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern of five separate `if` statements with only lower-bound checks is a classic source of overlapping ranges, and the incorrect multi-letter output follows directly from the code.

evidence.note: All conditions are independent `if` statements with overlapping ranges, so a single grade value can trigger multiple outputs.

misconceptions.name: Failure to utilize Scanner for required input
misconceptions.description: The student implemented logic for a completely different previous problem (distance calculation) and then hardcoded the input variable for the grade calculation instead of reading it from the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either copied code from a previous problem entirely or failed to delete irrelevant code, and subsequently hardcoded the input value, believing that providing a single test case within the code fulfills the requirement of reading input from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must actively prompt the user and read data using the Scanner object (e.g., `input.nextInt()` or `input.nextDouble()`) to satisfy the 'reads a numeric grade' requirement.
symptoms: Program outputs the same result every time (A B C D) regardless of user input (because there is no user input for the grade)
Code includes logic for an unrelated previous problem (Distance calculation)
misconceptions.root_cause: Reusing inappropriate code structures and failing to implement the required input mechanism.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the distance calculation code. Use the initialized `Scanner` object to read the grade from the user, replacing the hardcoded `int grade = 95;` line.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Clear evidence of distance calculation code and subsequent hardcoded grade input (95).

evidence.note: The student included code for calculating distance and hardcoded the grade variable (int grade = 95;) instead of reading input for the grade calculator problem.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding independent vs. chained conditionals (if vs. if-else if)
misconceptions.description: The student used a sequence of independent `if` statements instead of `if-else if` blocks. When a `grade` satisfies the first condition (e.g., A), it often satisfies all subsequent lower conditions (B, C, D), causing multiple incorrect letter grades to be printed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that each `if` statement evaluates its condition independently, but fails to realize that once one condition is met, subsequent independent checks should be skipped if mutual exclusion is desired. The student likely believes the positive check (e.g., `>= 90`) is sufficient without specifying the upper bound for the lower grades (e.g., `< 90`).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To ensure that only one outcome (A, B, C, D, or F) is printed, conditional checks for mutually exclusive ranges must be chained using `if`, `else if`, and `else` constructs. This guarantees that only the first true condition executes.
symptoms: The program prints multiple letter grades for a single input (e.g., 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' for a grade of 95).
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between independent sequential logic and mutually exclusive branching logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Convert the sequence of five `if` statements into an `if-else if-else` structure to ensure only one branch executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses five sequential independent IF statements when a single selection structure is required.

evidence.note: Uses independent 'if' statements instead of chained 'if-else if' structure, leading to multiple letter grades being printed for a high score.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Mutually exclusive conditions using separate if statements
misconceptions.description: Student uses separate if statements to handle mutually exclusive grade ranges, causing all applicable conditions to execute rather than selecting one. When grade=95, the code prints 'A', 'B', 'C', and 'D' instead of just 'A'.
misconceptions.student_belief: Separate if statements can be used to implement mutually exclusive conditions; the program will print only one letter grade based on which condition(s) are true.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To implement mutually exclusive conditions, use an if-else-if chain. Each if/else-if evaluates in sequence, and once a condition is true, the block executes and remaining conditions are skipped. Separate if statements evaluate independently, so all true conditions will execute.
symptoms: Multiple letter grades print for a single input (e.g., 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' all print for grade 95)
Condition structure fails to be mutually exclusive
misconceptions.root_cause: Student does not understand that separate if statements execute independently. May come from confusing if/else-if syntax or not realizing that each if is a separate evaluation rather than part of a chain.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the five separate if statements with an if-else-if-else chain: if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { ... }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern is clear and repeated: five separate if statements all evaluating independently. The evidence is concrete—when run with grade=95, all four conditions (>= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60) will be true and all will print. This is a textbook example of the misconception.

evidence.note: Each if statement is independent. When grade=95: all of >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60 are TRUE, so A, B, C, D all print instead of just A.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded grade instead of reading from user input
misconceptions.description: Student hardcodes the grade value as grade = 95 instead of reading it from user input via the Scanner object. The Scanner is created but never used to read the actual grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The grade can be set to a fixed value for testing purposes, or the student forgot to implement the input reading step.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade must be read from the user at runtime using Scanner. Use input.nextInt() after prompting the user with 'Enter grade: '.
symptoms: Program always processes grade 95 regardless of user input
Prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of asking for a grade
Scanner object created but not used to read the grade value
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation. Student may have tested with a hardcoded value and forgot to replace it with actual input reading, or submitted incomplete code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace int grade = 95; with a proper input prompt and read: System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The evidence is explicit: line 21 shows int grade = 95; which is a hardcoded literal value. This is not a matter of interpretation.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95. The assignment should have read: int grade = input.nextInt(); after prompting the user.
